This is a 3D puzzle of a mammoth. It is made of 1 mm plywood by using a CO2 Laser Cutter.
Last weeks I looked for designs of animals. I found some animal models, but the most models were to big or the connection of the parts were bad. So I made a new constructions of all models by using a CAD program. I scaled them, corrected some mistakes in the models und made a good connection between the puzzle parts.
more information and other projects you will find under: www.mydsgn.de or www.jtronics.de/modellbau.html

description.text:
Scaled, extended, and strengthened to handle compressing the rings on a 90mm piston, such as for Saab 9-3 engines.

I use vise grips to squeeze the two tabs together, then tap the outer skin of the ring compressor with a rubber mallet to close/equalize any gaps seen between the piston and the compressor. For me, the gap closed effectively all the way, allowing plenty of clearance to tap the piston down into the cylinder.

remixed_from.author: pheneeny
remixed_from.title: AM8 - Metal Frame for Anet A8

remixed_from.author: multithingverse
remixed_from.title: RepRap Prusa i3 Adjustable Y Belt Holder 44mm to 35mm

description.text:
As I was considering to convert my A8 to AM8, I thought it should be possible to modify the build plate area as well.
These are the parts I created in order to accommodate an Y carriage for a 200x300 heated bed, without having to cut in the Y carriage to make space for the motor in the original mounting position (and not having to mount the motor on the back of the frame).
Also, I increased the Z axis to approx 350mm with the standard X axis carriage, by using 550mm extrusions (requires longer threaded and smooth rods).

The challenge of using a larger buildplate without cutting in it can be approached in 4 ways:

  1. Raise the Y carriage using spacers on the bearing blocks on the Y carriage, and thereby reducing the printing height (Z axis)
  2. Raise the Y carriage by using spacers on the Y rod holders (or design new Y rod holders), and thereby reducing the printing height (Z axis)
  3. Lower the position of the Y motor - making tensioning the Y belt a bit more difficult, but does not reduce Z height.
  4. Place the Y motor on the back of the frame

I decided to go for option 3, in order to avoid decreasing my printing height (Z axis) - and to keep the Y motor inside the frame.

I changed the Y extrusion aluminum profiles to 480mm, and I use 500mm long 8mm smooth rods for the Y axis and Z axis.
The back of the Z axis extrusions are located 195mm from the back of the printer when using the X carriage https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2193695 (I think this measurement is 127mm on the original AM8).

The center of the heated bed need to be calibrated after build - check for example https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2280529 on how to do it.

The Y motor and Y belt idler mount are mounted on the inside of the frame - and the belt holder/tensioner is located on the bottom side of the Y carriage. I know this makes tensioning the belt harder/more difficult - but again: how many times do you need to tighten the belt, if you use a quality-belt ?

The Y carriage I use for my modification: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Large-Size-Aluminum-Y-Carriage-Plate-XL-300x200mm-Prusa-i3-RepRap-3D-Printer-Upgrade/32727730118.html

Y belt holder/tightener was inspired by https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:896911

I have added https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2067676 as Z anti-wobble - which required me to lower the Z motor mounts all the way down, so that they touch the frame stabilizer plate for the Z axis.

Update 20170802:
Y motor mount v3 added - this one does not require screws/bolts in the top of the extrusion, but will hook into the slot in top of the extrusion for better stability.

Update 20170818:
Z rod holder (only included for left side, mirror it in your slicer for the right side version) was modified from the original to avoid the threaded rod from moving too much, as I also extended the Z axis during my modification.

Update 20170828:
New Y motor mount, new Y idler and new belt holder/tensioner. Position of belt raised 10mm higher - closer to the carriage, in order to minimize the risk of any wobble...
Y rod mounts added - with end-stops in order to be able to use 500mm rods with the 480mm Y extrusions.

Update 20170917:
Added Y belt holder/tensioner for 219x219 Y carriage (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2325206) - it has not been tested, feedback welcome. This part will probably need to be split up when printed - and supports are needed for the largest part.

Update 20171006:
Y endstop bracket /rod holder modified to pull endstop switch 4mm back.

Update 20171107:
New Y idler added (with a height, that will fit a 2020 extrusion). The idler pulley has been recessed/countersunk a bit into the mounting plate, giving 3 mm more room (less chance of collision with the Y belt holder/tightener).

Update 20171206:
On my original A8 I have had issues with the Z axis getting out of alignment. In order to avoid this, I have created two new Z rod mounts for the top with 22mm center distance (the original AM8 motor mounts have 22.2mm center distance - I will ass my own motor mounts later).
These Z top mounts will each be fitted with a KFL08 bearing on the bottom side of the bracket, and a 20T pulley mounted on the threaded rod. Besides this, a 20T toothed and a 20T smooth idle pulley will be needed on each side - and a GT2-900mm belt to connect the two sides.
The KFL08 bearing will be mounted from the bottom using 2 M5x12 screws with 2 M5 nuts on the top. The 20T idle-pulley (mounted to the center of the printer) with be installed using a M5x25 screw and a M5 locking-nut (and a nut on top to keep it in place). The 20T toothed idle pulley will be mounted in the "adjustment" position with a M5x35 screw and a locking nut (and a nut on top to keep it in place).
Mounting order:

  1. Insert M3 nut to be able to tighten smooth rod
  2. Mount the bracket on the AM8 frame
  3. Mount the KFL08 bearing
  4. Mount the smooth 20T idle pulley
  5. Insert the threaded rod, adjust the X axis in height - then adjust the pulley in the top of the threaded rod to align with the smooth pulley and tighten the screws of the pulley.
  6. Tighten the threaded rod in the flexible coupler in the bottom of the threaded rod
  7. Tighten the screws in the KFL08 bearing to the threaded rod
  8. Mount the toothed idle pulley - wait to tighten the screw
    Now mount the other side - same procedure - and then mount the 900mm belt. Now you can tighten the belt, and tighten the screws for the toothed idle pulleys.

I know some people will claim the will give Z wobble. This is true, unless you "mechanically" disconnect the threaded Z rods from the X carriages. That id why I use these (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2067676) on my Z axis.
Photos will be added later.

Printer:

Prusa I3 clone (Anet A8)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.12/0.20

Infill:

75% / 40%

Notes:

Y belt holder printed in 0.12mm / 75% infill / 2mm wall thickness
Other parts printed in 0.20mm / 40% infill / 2mm wall thickness
Motor mount printed with supports (touching buildplate only)

remixed_from.author: Agisis
remixed_from.title: Agisis Ultimate Alien Face Hugger (40in x 23in - LIFE SIZE!)

description.text:
This is a custom designed stand for the Agisis Facehugger model. I needed a stand and there wasn't one out there. Now there is. So print it. Paint it. Enjoy. I think it looks pretty sweet.

Download this.
Have fun.
Be good.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 stand, 0.15 plaque

Infill:

100% stand, 20% plaque

Finish and paint

I used a scalpel to trim down some of the print errors and then sanded it using progressively higher grit to smooth it nicely.

I mixed up some blue grey, black and silver acrylic to cover the parts. No primer, but 2 coats was enough. Then dry brush some silver for the highlights.

The hardest part was the yellow Weyland infill, I tried a thin yellow, but this wasn't enough to cover it. What I found worked was to water down to a consistency that just about hides brush marks. Fill the space, dry, repeat this about 5 times. I put it in front of a fan heater each time which dried it in about 5 minutes.

Hope this helps.

Why is this 2 part stand not a single part?

Honestly, I didn't think of doing the plaque until after the stand had come out, but I think it's better this way since the plaque can be replaced easily with an alternate. You could use different materials for each for instance. Also if the stand printing doesn't work out (it was pushing my printer to the limits) you haven't wasted a ton of time and material. They slot together seamlessly anyway so it no big deal.

title: Cyclone PCB Pillow Block Front Y Frame

description.text:
Wanted to clean up the geometry of Yoda and make a few fixes.

Heres a list of what's different from the legacy downloads:

  • Added pupils (eyes were round spheres in almost all versions)
  • Converted it into a solid mesh with no overlapping geometry.
  • Flipped inverted faces and plugged holes.
  • Added a plaque that should be printed separately so that the lettering quality can be controlled.
  • Added a base that should make the bust presentable.

title: Phone Stand/Holder With Option For Charging

description.text:
Fits nearly any phone (or tablet). Has capability to charge your phone while in the stand.

I made sure that there were enough space between the phone and the hole where the cable goes through, so that the cable will not be bend at a hard angle and thereby damage it.

There is two different designs to choose from, so you can pick the one that you like the best.
There is no difference between the two designs other than the looks.

If you have any suggestions for improvement, then please leave a comment where you describe the thing you have in mind, and I will do my best to improve the model over time.

Note that the normal version is for phones without cases, the extended version is for phones with cases and the extra extended version is for phones with very big cases.

Photos will be updated soon...

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

10% or more

Updates

update V 0.0.2 - 1/8/17 :

  • made the space where the phone is held 10mm instead of 15mm.

update V 0.1.0 - 1/8/17 :

  • made the bottom plate not stick out as much in the front.
  • removed the piece in the middel so you can plug your phone in to charge before setting it in the holder.
  • added 3 different sizes: 10mm for phones without cases - 13mm for phones with cases - 15mm for phone with very big cases.
  • the model will now lay as it is supposesd to be printed when you inport the model in to your slicer.

update V 0.1.1 - 1/8/17 :

  • made the bottom plate longer in the front accordingly to the size of the stand for more stabebility.

update V 0.1.2 - 2/8/17 :

  • minor visual updates.
  • added a "holder" to roud your cable through, to take off some of the stress from the cable if your cable is hanging off your desk or something like that that will drag on your cable.

update V 0.2.0 - 5/8/17 :

  • added a hole new design, so you now have two designs to choose from.
  • updated the pictures so they are now up to date with the actual model.

Included are cookie cutters for "Hungry Bears", "Justice Bear", and my original "Bear Cone".

I have been asked to include the Sugar Cookie Recipe I use, so a copy will be included with the STL files when you download this design set.

50%

Any infill will work, I just tend to always use 50% for my cookie cutters.

Protective tray and sleeve for the RunCam Split WiFi Module.

Now you can throw the Wifi module in your toolkit without worrying about the pins getting bent.

The sleeve and the tray have 0.4mm of space between them and rely on a friction fit. There are little nubs on the sides of the tray to provide the right amount of friction to keep them together. If it's a little tight after you have printed it, slide the tray in and out a few times and it should loosen up a little.

Printer:

Anet a8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Wall width is 1.2mm which equates to 3 layers with a 0.4mm nozzle, so I had to set my line width at 0.35 and wall line count to 1 layer in order for Cura to add the middle layer and not do two lines separated by an air gap.
No supports required.

title: Geartar
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
UPDATE 1: I have added a little video here for you to see all the gears moving:

https://youtu.be/DH4wXGN3lu0

I have here my 3D printed guitar.

follow me on instagram (you will see videos of the guitar in action dont forget to like it there!)
hugo archicad

I have zero music knowledge.

My friend Steve has a band called 44 inch chest and he saw the guitar on YouTube that was 3D printed and jokingly asked me to make one just like it for him.

I said I would need a donor guitar first so one day he got one at a flea market.

Then it sat in my wardrobe for about 6 months until one day I couldn't think of what to 3D print next so I started.

In terms of parts I used the donor guitar, pulled it all apart then I photocopied it and started modeling.
I had to reduce the body by 97% to get it to fit on my cr-10 because it did say it had a 300x300x400 high but the reality was a little smaller.
I did not shrink anything else only the body.
So I used the gears from a thingiverse post that someone else had made already.
I did not shrink anything else.
Because of the 97% I had to cut away a little of the wooden handle thing because it would not slot perfectly because although it was modeled to fit I couldn't fit it on the printer bed.

List of things you need to make this guitar:

about 2 kilos of pla -1 mini servo motor which I had to open to make sure it would do full rotation( I found the answer on YouTube) -1 EL wire (1 meter)(red) with its electronic part. -1 battery holder (2xaa) for the servo -glue (clear for the EL wire) -glue to stick the main guitar pieces, the bottom lid has a groove on its top for the glue to go on so it doesnt lift the lid too much with the thickness of the glue blob -wire to add length to the componets and that tube thing that you put on the wires that shrinks when you put it under heat or cigar lighter (I dont know the name but better than using electrical tape looks so professional with it and all the soldering stays put)
I wanted to fit the servo motor battery inside the guitar, I left a space there but I couldn't at the end because I couldn't get the EL wire to work without its little box ( there is some electronic stuff in it that I couldn't get out of the box so it sits outside.
I would like to find a way to fit it inside (my electronic know how is not the best)
I did managed to solder all the connections and connect a switch (a key that turns the servo on).

I designed everything to conceal the wiring and made hidden little tunnels to run the wiring, and also made a little channel to run the EL wire through cleanly.

I don't know if my donor guitar is like other guitars so the design I have made works for this guitar but don't know if it would work on others.

Nu supports needed at all anywhere.

A nice big 3D printer would be nice but nothing stopping anyone from cutting it up in pieces.
If you do end up cutting it in pieces do not shrink anything then everything will work perfectly.

Enjoy

I know i did designing it and putting it together.

Also when putting screws i learned that if you put your soldering iron on top of the screw for a bit and hold it there, the heat transfers to the plastic making it easier to screw then when its cooled its stick super well.

One thing...the gears are not my design, i got them from here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2218127
And have added them here so you can download everything you need from one place.

3D PRINTING SETTINGS

I used no supports
2 rolls of black PLA, and a bit of red for the gears.
I have one gear that is a little too tight in there, I suggest you print the gears a few times and see what colours work best.
you do not need all the gears I added BUT you might want to make a belt or something to hold the guitar.

I used cura so I used 1.75 nozzle, 30% infill for the main body.
BUT for the little gear holders I made them 70% infill as at first the little bits broke off but not when I made them stronger.
the gears were all 30% infill.

follow me on instagram (you will see videos of the guitar in action dont forget to like it there!)
hugo archicad

title: Warlord Titan
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
So I've been getting a lot of messages about what I've been working on lately ... well, here you go.
This is still a big work in progress, but i thought i would go ahead and release what i have now. Just in case someone wanted to get started printing.

Follow the Explosion STL files for visual instructions on how all of the parts go together.

Few notes:

  • I am not incredibly happy with how i sliced the shin, I may rework it later
  • The hydraulics for the toes were too small for my printer to print correctly. I used tiny Plastruct tubes instead.
  • The armor pieces for the hip hydraulics were also a bit too small for my printer to print correctly, so I have uploaded two larger size options. The one in the image is 1pt3x

UPDATE:
Torso is complete :) I know it's been awhile but I'm almost done. Only thing left now is just the guns. The holes in the upper/outer left and right shoulder bits are for where the gun points will mount (the ones above and below) So don't cover them up. Unless you want a titan without guns ... I suppose it doesn't matter too much, it could still just stomp the bad guys to death. But I digress. And again, follow the explosion stl for instructions.

Few more notes:

  • The power tubs for the head don't print so well. Use wires from a broken power supply, or Christmas wire, or metal coat hanger, or something else ... you get the idea.
  • The catwalk is too small for my printer to print correctly. I built mine out of Plastruct.
  • The eagle on the hood above the head comes out a bit thin. When printing consider making it twice as tall/thick.
  • You might want to wait to glue the Shoulder_Upper_Outside_L/R pieces to the rest of the model until the gun mounts are ready. You will need to make sure the bottom slot of the Shoulder_Upper_Outside_L/R lines up with the open slot of Shoulder_Lower_L/R.
  • There are two versions of the head. One with supports and one without. My machine doesn't always do the best job when it comes to auto generating supports.

Update:
Guns are complete, which means this entire project is complete, which means ... thank goodness because this was a lot of work. The top guns slide right in. For the lower guns, you need to detach the torso from the legs and push them into their slots at a 45° angle from the front. Then rotate around until it locks into place. It's important to line up your entry points properly, otherwise it may be a tight turn.

Few more notes:

  • For the lower guns use the ScrewPin_v2. The star head of the screw will allow you to set the front facing of the gun. It's important that the top part of the screw head is perpendicular to the gun itself.
  • The pipes on the vents were too thin for my printer and didn't come out well. ... I just left them off, didn't seem to add much visual for me. If you really want them I suppose you could make some out of Plastruct.
  • The eagles on the barrels also did not come out well. I ended up cleaning them off. Perhaps a sticker or painting will be best suited to fix this.
  • I wanted the weapons for this to be a bit modular, so I made this in such a way that you do not need to glue the guns in place.

title: Kodi LCDproc for Raspberry Pi and Odroid C2

description.text:
A simple Kodi / LibreELEC box / case / mount for your Odroid C2 or Raspberry Pi.

  • Has rubber feet to stop HDMI cable from moving unit around (also hides M3 screws).
  • I have uploaded both 16x2 and 20x4 versions (depending on how large your screen size is).
  • Odroid version has a hole to pass through IR.

SketchUp source files are included.

LCD to LCD Mount = M3 x 14mm
Base to LCD Mount = M3 x 12mm (or M3 x 10mm without feet).

Not required, but if you want to get fancy:
Use the spare M3 holes (Odroid C2 version) to attach a 3D printed logo / letter / etc. Print the IR pot in transparent filament (the IR beam will pass through just fine). You can cover up the LCD back area with some foil tape (kills the light bleed). Use 12mm x 12mm rubber feet on the bottom to cover the M3 holes.

To enable I2C on Pi (skip this for Odroid) - enable SSH then:

mount -o remount,rw /flash
nano /flash/config.txt

Add to the end of the file:
dtparam=i2c_arm=on,spi=on
dtparam=act_led_trigger=none
dtparam=act_led_activelow=off
dtparam=pwr_led_trigger=none
dtparam=pwr_led_activelow=off

For both Odroid and Pi:

Install XMBC LCDproc and LCDproc under services.
Add-ons > Download > Install from repository > Kodi Add-on repository > Services > XBMC LCDproc
Add-ons > Download > Install from repository > LibreELEC Add-ons > Services > LCDproc

nano ~/.kodi/userdata/addon_data/service.lcdd/LCDd.conf
(if this file doesn't exist, simply configure the hd44780 driver via the Kodi GUI (LCDproc) and it will automatically be created.

Make the following changes:
Driver=hd44780
[hd44780]
ConnectionType=i2c
Port=0x27
Device=/dev/i2c-1
i2c_line_RS=0x01
i2c_line_RW=0x02
i2c_line_EN=0x04
i2c_line_BL=0x08
i2c_line_D4=0x10
i2c_line_D5=0x20
i2c_line_D6=0x40
i2c_line_D7=0x80
Size=16x2 (or leave as 20x4)

Reboot and enjoy.

http://marcuswolschon.blogspot.de/2014/01/leaving-thingiverse.html

Just a parametric quick release plate compatible with Manfrotto 200PL and Calumet 1/4-20" and Calumet 3/8-16"
Description
Includes a custom fit 1/4"-20 UNC bolt with handle.
(standard camera thread)
It is tappered to make inserting it into a proper thread-cutter easier.
You MAY try using a 1/4-20 nut instead but this hasn't been tested.
(I'm using the proper tools for the proper job.) The 200pl_GH2.* files are a special version of the adapter plate that allows the battery door of the Panasonic GH1 and GH2 cameras to still open. You can change the parameters to make a 3/8-16 UNC bolt instead.
You can also chane the depth of the nut on your camera. The default is 7mm (works on all of mine).
The plate is already exported for 1/2-20 UNC and 3/8-16 UNC.

title: Anet A8 Tronxy Bed level sensor Mount (Right side)

description.text:
I found myself not happy with the included mount due to not detecting the bed on occasion. So I made this mount. It is partially from the design of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2426460
I loved the mount until it kept breaking and tangling with my heated bed. So here we are, the spring loaded design from MaddeMichael. Plus my own mount location design.

you will need some of the extra screws and nuts from building your printer.
The mount does fit between the print head and right-hand side Z axis threaded rod.
you will need to change your sensor location offset's in your configuration.h file
the new settings I am using successfully:

define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 48
define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -15

I hope you find this design helpful.

Again, thanks to MaddeMichael https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2426460

description.text: This is a gimbal and switch protector the the Flysky FS-I6X Transmitter. It clips on where the lanyard would go. It may work with the Flysky FS-I6 but I don't have a transmitter to test it on. If someone prints it for the I6 and it fits please leave a comment. This design was inspired by spudinator after making a protector that included switches. I still wanted more protection so I created this one with full covers and also wanted it to clip-on.

Yes

0.2 mm Layer Height

20%

Notes:

After printing I used a heat gun to bend the switch covers into place. I also used the heat gun to fit everything a little better to the controller. You can also use the heat gun to adjust the clip-on part to make it more snug if you prefer. Don't be heating it up while its on the transmitter either!

Printed Material: PLA
I will probably re-print this in PETG because I will know this will be sitting in my car and I don't want to worry about the the protector warping on a hot day.

• Apple TV
• Samsung 4k TV
• other media remotes up to 40mm wide x 22mm deep.

Approx. 75 - 80 grams in filament weight.

Updated August 3rd, 2017: better pockets for holding pens upright.

Updated August 11th, 2017: reduced internal walls to 1mm. Item is now printed with 65 - 70 grams in filament.

author: Digital-Ed

description.text: My brother got jealous of my custom spinner (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2461660) so I made him this. Now he flips a balisong like me, and doesn't want it. So I'll give it to you guys instead!

So I noticed people were selling 3D printed models based on iPhone X leaks, why should people pay for that, especially with unconfirmed rumours? These models are for the people, but you absolutely must not use them for any kind of profit generation, no consent for that has been given.

There is a detailed model made specifically for making 3D renders, it has more than 20 individual bodies for separate parts which require their own texture, the renders made and shown here were done so using this file. You can of course print this file but you will get a quite bland looking shape.

There is a model for single extruders, it has defined areas for the screen, logos, front and rear cameras etc, this is achieved by varying the thickness of the model.

There are two separate models for dual extruders, I've used Black and White to make the model shown in the photograph, this makes models that have a standardised thickness and so use the alternate colours for definition.

Lastly there are a few extra bits including a schematic PDF that you can use to make fitted wallpapers, just for these files.

I must state that the dimensions used are those found on the internet somewhere, there are new leaks coming out every day so these could easily be wrong, don't therefore use these models to make cases or anything like that because you'll probably be disappointed later.

Anyway have fun and if you make anything cool I'd love to see! Cheers.

title: Card Deck Case with press
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Poker deck case with a special cover.
Designed for bicycle "raider" decks or similar.

The cover is designed to work as a card press.
The latches offer the possibility to wrap a rubber band around.
This band holds the case closed and provides already a slight pressure to the cards.
But of course you can add more rubber band on different positions to increase the pressure.

For better handling I uploaded a version without the latches for the rubber band.
Press function is still included, of course.

The hole in the cover helps to identify the deck or can be filled with an colored/designed insert.

This is an adapter to replace the gear set inside the PG35L stepper motor to give a 1 to 1 gear ratio. Since no modifications are made to the stepper besides replacing the gear set it can be later reverted back to the original gear ratio. I have included pics of the disassembled stepper gear box. Just pry the 3 metal tabs gently and it comes right apart. Remove the floating 3 gear gear set and replace with this adapter. I used some synthetic super lube on the end of the adapter toward the stepper motor, the other end does not need any. When putting it back together, you will need to gently press the 3 tabs back in place.

Since the tolerances are really close and I know it will print a little different on different printers I have included the FreeCad file so you can modify as needed. I have also included a snapshot of the Kisslicer V1.6 Beta 2.4 settings I used to print it. I did not use any cooling fan. I used Atomic Filament CF PETG to print it and IMO it came out very good considering the size of gear details and also the fact that I was using a 0.4 hard steel nozzle. (My only hard steel nozzle)

The reason I designed this is to attempt to use it with one of my Zesty Nimble cable driven extruders since it has less mass than the NEMA 17 I am using and appears to be a 7.5 degree motor. It may however not have enough torque to drive the Nimble. I will update when I get the opportunity to try it.
Designed with Freecad
I used a modified Ultibots K250 delta with metal corners, Duet WiFi, 0.9 steppers, and custom Zesty Nimble magball effector.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/22w21BAAtCI

author: mariomsyano

description.text:
Este proyecto se trata de un simple chasis impreso en 3D que he hecho como una base de prueba para una plataforma de robótica. Traté de hacer que tuvieran tantas piezas no impresas como sea posible, para maximizar el número de personas que podrían usarlo. Lo imprimí todo en plástico ABS, y se ha mantenido bien - sin partes rotas todavía !.
Usos
Este chasis podría ser utilizado como un simple coche RC, o para algunas plataformas de robótica (lo construí para probar el procesamiento de la visión con un Pi de frambuesa). Además, con su alta velocidad, esto podría incluso ser utilizado para correr cada uno otro robot!
Limitaciones
Debido a que sólo utiliza una caja de cambios de una sola etapa, este bot es RÁPIDO. Una vez que los engranajes en el desgaste, se puede ejecutar sin problemas con bajos voltajes, pero no tiene mucho par para tirar de peso o para conducir lentamente.
Esta base también es muy corta y ancha, ya que la aplicación que diseñé para ello lo requirió. Si se agrega demasiado peso en alto, puede volverse fácil de inclinar. Sin embargo, se puede enderezar fácilmente. De hecho, si colocas toda la electrónica de control junto a los motores, y no en la parte superior, este robot podría voltear boca abajo y seguir funcionando bien.

Sigue el proyecto en https://www.todossomosmaker.com/inicio/impresion-3d/chasis-simple-impreso-en-3d

title: Filament Guide for Tronxy Prusa All Metal (Two Ways)

description.text:
This is a Guide for the filament in the All-Metal Tronxy Prusa i3. Mine was sold by Rojo3D (in Argentina).
This gives you a "bowden style" way to feed the hotend. The filament does not grind over the feed hole anymore.
Also, is able to work two ways: with the filament above the center wheel, or below it.

A nice thing is the threaded rod and nut to attach it through the printer's frame hole, so you can put it in every angle.

Just needs three 608 ball bearings (the ones used for spinners).
SHORTER VERSION:
I made a different version (indicated by "_short"), with the center wheel nearer to the side wheels, so the filament stays always in between wheels. It works better when the printer heads moves back and the filament has to move backwards.

For the less friction possible, use the TUSH (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2047554) as a spool holder.

Made in Sketchup. Feel free to modify it in order to use it with your printer frame.

Printer:

Tronxy Prusa i3 All Metal

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Do NOT print the same half of the frame twice if you plan to use the rod and nut.
For Wheels, just print first ONE half and test it with your ball bearing. If it doesn't fit tight enough, stretch or squeeze it a little bit until you are good to print 5 more. For me: 40,3mm diameter worked.
The thread rod halves need support. I use the Cura "Enable Support Roof" Feature (I don't know if it's Cura's exclusive) for a clean surface, with support Z Distance at twice of Layer Height (0,15 -> 0,3).
At least 30% infill just in case you need to re-attach it or remove the wheels. If not, you can rip off the wheel supports.

author: UnsaneMonkey

description.text:
UPDATE: Someone pointed out that perhaps there was a bit too much geometry for Adalinda.  In the interests of keeping people happy, I have uploaded a decimated version.  
Adalinda was briefly on CNBC being used as a demo model at the NYC 3D printing conference.  Many thanks to Anoroc for letting me know and for using her for his demonstration:-)  
"Once a century, Adalinda flies to the top of the highest mountain in the realm and sings for her love who died so long ago"  
I am sure dragons can sing. Here is Adalinda, a female dragon whose song is the most haunting of all.  
I've had it on my mind for a while to build a dragon, but I wanted to make one that didn't require supports or assembly and here she is.  Tolkien style Dragons are not generally shaped to avoid overhang, so the design took some experimentation and thought as I didn't want to compromise too much with shapes.  
You will need to use lots of cooling when printing her with PLA.  With ABS, an enclosed environment is preferred as too much cooling will cause the model to crack  
I have built her with an open mouth and hollow throat because I wanted her to really look as though she is singing, so don't be surprised at the partial hollow when printing.  
Adalinda was sculpted using Blender.

Adalinda prints without supports.
You will need to use lots of cooling when printing her with PLA.  With ABS, an enclosed environment is preferred as too much cooling will cause the model to crack  
You need to ensure your filament is measured as precisely as it can be (so your flowrate is correct) as the model will show up excess material really easily and it will spoil the clarity of the print.   
Infill can be very low. I printed the gold model with a .1 infill.  
The model prints at 14.7cm high, but looks good printed smaller scale too.

comments.author: ABW-3D

comments.text: Decimate is a common way to describe polygon count reduction in 3D modelling.  If you were to put the two Adalindas in a 3D modelling program (like Meshmixer, for example), you would see the number of polygons is different. The smaller number of polygons the less work the slicer has to do.

comments.text:
I just printed this at 120% (176mm) in PLA and it came out fantastic. I think I'm going to do one at 140% next. That should be near the volume limits of my Kossel delta. The detail is definitely there to support it.
I knew by looking that this would be a problem printing in ABS, as most ABS has a tendency to curl at the tips of overhangs even in a fully enclosed machine. The printhead hits those curls on each layer and the risk of breaking is very real.
The PLA print was fairly easy, but definitely benefited from having the layer cooling fan turned up pretty high.

comments.text: Just got done printing this with black ABS and scaled down 50%. It turned out beautifully until I tried to take the raft off and both front arms broke off, haha! Next time I'll be sure to not print with a raft. Great model though!
comments.author: ten16

comments.text: Oh no!  She is a bit delicate but I didn't want to make her limbs more robust because in my mind, she is very much a girl dragon and whilst she should look strong, she should also look graceful.  What I do to minimize potential breakage is print slowly and then put the bed with the model on in the freezer for a while: she'll then pop off on her own.
comments.author: ten16

comments.text: Adalinda is about 2 hours into her print and looking great so far :) This is a beautiful model. I would love to learn how to sculpt/model something like this but I have no idea where to begin, can you recommend any tutorials? I use Cinema4D and have used Blender a little too but things I make are not  an organic shape like this.
comments.author: 999dom999

comments.text: With Adalinda, I made some sketches which I used as guides during the sculpt, so I could keep in mind proportions and her look but using photographs can work just as well.  This didn't mean I didn't change things along the way though.  Blender is a great bit of software to explore, but can be daunting to start with. I can highly recommend the BlenderCookie site which has some great tutorials using all kinds of building methods (there are a lot) and they are aimed at all levels of experience. There is a paid section to the site but they also offer a lot of free tutorials.

comments.text:
I don't really know, but: If you have got a 2 extruder printer, perhaps with a light-conducting (or glow-in-the-dark) filament you can print a type of fiber optics leading from stomach to the eyes? Perhaps you could change the model (perhaps simple openscad) and make a multi material STL, in the core the optical conducting filament, the outer side some light tight filament?
Perhaps it is enough, just to make thin canals and print with light tight filament, after that just put the leds in the stomach?
Some stearin waxes (I think, you should not use paraffine with PLA) have some light conductive attributes, perhaps it works...or take glycerin...I could imagine some really nice looking Adalindas...

comments.text: ABS is brittle and is prone to snapping with thin or delicate models.  I suggest slicing the model to print more slowly so it does get shaken so much when printing the 'fiddly' bits.

comments.text: This comment has made me correct my instructions.  Basically, the deal is that this model will show up any excess material and it will spoil the clarity of the print.  I suggest setting up individual profiles for each type of filament you have with precise measurements to ensure that you don't extrude more than needed.  With many models you can get away with it, but with this dragon it will have an impact on the overall look.

I got 4 way joystick for my arcade bartop and I wanted a 8 way restrictor plate, I did a search and I found nothing, only a 4 way joystick restrictor and an adapter, unfortunately my joystick didnt had the choice to adapt a 8 way restrictor, so I just combined the 4 way joystick restrictor to the 8 way adapter, and it worked!

author: Animedia

title: CR-10 Filament Run-Out Sensor Switch Box

description.text:
I designed this switch box around the cr-10 stock Z axis end stop switch. I will be linking this switch through Octoprint. It was originally removed from my cr-10 to install the ABL auto leveling sensor. This freed up the old z axis stop to be used for my filament run-out switch. As you can see in the picture with the red plate bracket that the end stop was originally mounted on, I duplicated the T-like indented pattern in this switch box. It's a simple box. Nothing fancy. I've included the Autodesk Inventor file (.ipt file) for anyone who wants or needs to modify it. In light of that, after it's printed check the filament feed hole. In order to get an extra smooth feed hole I've carefully drilled the hole out with a 5/64th drill bit. You might not need to do that though. Modify as needed. Also, the jpeg picture of the part in the software is the actual part. That version adds a little more room above the filament so its not rubbing the wall. The same 2 screws that mounted the end stop were used. If those have been misplaced, I'm not sure what size they are. sorry.

Also, in one of the picture you'll see a ribbon cable. This was a 24" JST 2S extension cable bought off ebay.

NOTE: If you were one of the first couple people that downloaded the stl, know that a corrected version has been uploaded. A previous version that had a wrong filament hole placement was accidentally used when the part was first uploaded.

comments.text:
Very nice! Could you please tell a bit more about "linking this switch through Octoprint"?
Thanks!

comments.text: The filament sensors included in the newer CR-10's are exactly the same - just the standard end stop in a box.

remixed_from.title: printrbot simple fan duct and tensioner

title: Printrbot Jr. V2 60mm side fan mount and duct

description.text:
NEW: I've made plates and a fan-less latch to match the same style in this design here, they go great with this so please take a look: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:248333
NEW: A 40mm fan design (uses same plates above to match): http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:248367 This is version 4.1 (earlier versions are included)
4.1
more clearence, better airflow, less plastic used, cooler design, but also harder to print? (print with supports)
3.1
adjusted cross again, trimmed a bit off the parts that slide into the base
3.0
-adjusted cross positioning, sunk motor screw holes in a bit, style is more consistent Didn't like the wobble in the fan when there was a lot of shake on the z-axis and it also bothered me that the fan was attached to the one thing that I move the most on the extruder. (refering to this design, the only one i found for 60mm: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:231661 ) So I built this to ease up the stress on the fan blades and reduce wobble, It also helps reduce warping that I found occurs when you strap large fans onto the extruder without ducts. built specifically for use with Printrbot Jr. v2. However, it may work with Simple.... I presume (I haven't tested it). The original plate design came from a simple extruder drawing ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:248333http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:175718 ) and I made a few modifications (the position of the nut holder cross is increaed and moved, the alan screw holes were increased, but the basic shape is the same) Going to make something like this to go with it next ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:240397 ) so that the front is only a filiment latch and not a shaky fan mount. Also included: my Version 1, which was accidentally dimensioned for a printrbot simple. note that its a two piece design and the bottom of the design, when installed, may be really really close to the platform... maybe take a sander to it or something.

comments.text: Question... for anyone out there who might know: these pieces I'm making for the printrbot Jr. v2 extruder... is this any infringement of copyright/patents? Im taking their publicly released sketches for the printrbot simple direct drive extruder and modifying them to fit the jr. (as well as aesthetic changes). If anyone knows if I may or may not be bordering on someone elses design rights please tell me and I will act accordingly.

author: helno

description.text: This is a 55mm diameter shifter knob model. Fits NA/NB manual miatas. Thread M10x1.25.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

100um

Infill:

70%

This a fully printable 4-axis Trammel of Archimedes. It's designed with printing ease in mind: all of the parts print without any supports, and all that you'll need to assemble everything is a little bit of sandpaper and glue.

Check below for detailed printing and assembly instructions. If you liked this design, please feel free to let me know in the comments. Happy printing!

Important note:
These parts are designed with no tolerances. I will designate which parts need to be scaled down and also provide the parameters I used, but it will be best practice to print singular parts (e.g. a singular slider) to check for your own printer/material.

(1) Print 1 Base Block.stl. This part is quite large and will thus determine the final size of the project. (Obviously, if you scale this part, all other parts must be appropriately scaled and if applicable re-scaled.) Printing at full scale took around 7 hours for me, about the same amount of time as all other parts put together.
(2) Print 4 of Slider.stl. (Scale this part down!) I scaled my slider down to 97.5% of its original size, creating a ~0.5mm tolerance which worked nicely.
(3) Print 4 of Slider Pin.stl. (Scale this part to the same scale as Slider.stl)
(4) Print 1 Guide Bracket.stl.
(5) Print 1 Crank Pin.stl. (Scale this part down!) I again used 97.5%, and that worked nicely.
(6) Print 1 Knurled Sleeve.stl or Plain Sleeve.stl. (Scale this part vertically only!) I used a knurled sleeve for the print pictured (at 0.6mm resolution for better quality), but if the details are too fine, I've also included a plain sleeve. Regardless of which one you use, you'll want to scale it down vertically so that it will fit between the guide bracket and the crank cap.
(7) Print 1 Crank Cap.stl. (Scale this part to the same scale as Crank Pin.stl)

Once all your parts have been printed, gather them together with some glue and some sandpaper or a file.

(1) Make sure your parts fit/slide as appropriate! The sliders should be able to easily slide through the base block without feeling loose or wobbling side to side as you move them. The slider pins should fit snugly all the way down into the slider. A little bit of sanding on the end of the pin should ensure a better fit. The crank sleeve should rotate freely around the crank pin, and the crank cap should fit snugly onto the crank pin.
(2) Put the crank pin through the hole at the end of the guide bracket. The square base should fit into the square receptacle.
(3) Slide the crank sleeve over the crank pin and put the crank cap on top. The sleeve should spin loosely around the cap. (I had to sand the crank sleeve down to get it to fit vertically since I forgot to scale it earlier; learn from my mistakes!) If the parts fit well, then glue the crank pin to the guide bracket and the crank cap to the crank pin, effectively trapping the crank sleeve in place.
(4) Put all four sliders into the block, making sure that there is one in each channel of the base block.
(5) Line the sliders up with the guide bracket, then insert the slider pins down through the guide holes into the sliders themselves. See the images above for reference.
(6) Make sure that everything moves well. I had to round some of the edges on my sliders with a razor blade and do a bit of filing/sanding to make everything super smooth, but it didn't take long. Once you're happy with how everything moves, dab some glue into each slider (not too much or the guide bracket will glue itself to each slider too), then press the whole assembly together. I suggest cranking slowly as the glue dries to avoid the possibility of sticking a slider to the guide bracket.
(7) Crank away!

This project was the result of a self-taught introduction to OnShape, a fantastic, FREE cloud-based CAD software. All parts and animations were created with OnShape. I had a great experience using it to create this project, and I highly recommend for newcomers to CAD like myself.

title: Track Cog / Fixed Gear Sprocket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
DO NOT TRY AND USE THIS
It's just for decoration. That's it and that's all, man.

It is anatomically correct and mechanically functional, though. I was really impressed when the printed threads actually let me put this on my hub. Maybe I'll make a colorful or glow in the dark one to put on the unused side of my hub.

This is modeled after the best cog, the Shimano Dura-Ace Track Cog. It comes in 13 to 17 teeth, so this one does too.

FULL versions have the recessed lockring cutout on the bottom, tapered teeth, and hub threads. Most or all of these things are useless and just make the thing harder to print. I enabled supports for the lockring recession and tapered teeth but it got messy, see how ugly the underside is? But I wanted to go fully authentic. Maybe your printer is better.

NO RECESSION version is just like the full version but lacks the lockring recession. This makes the bottom/outside flat, easy to print, and nicer looking. If you want to thread on a decorative pink cog to your non drive side, this is probably the one to do, as it's still 'functional' since you shouldn't bother with a lockring, but looks and prints better.

SIMPLE versions are missing the above features, but still retains the identifiable shape. I think this would be good for printing scaled-down versions for little keychains and stuff, or for people not trying for a difficult print.

FLAT versions are missing the extended thread area, so these will be very simple to print, very appropriate for cosmetic projects, keychains, stickers, badges, etc.

In the picture showing three sizes, the large one is Full at normal size, the keychain is Simple at 50% size, the nickel is Flat at 30% size.

Again, this is not intended to actually be used; even if you have a metal printer I'm pretty sure commercial versions of this are very strong.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.0875

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Concentric patterns for top/bottom look best and are very satisfying to watch print.

100% infill is probably worth it, for me, I couldn't even really choose less since the part was so thin and the top/bottom layers were thick.

I did supports for the tapered teeth and lockring recession, but this was probably more trouble than it was worth.

Randomized the z-seam since my printer seems to be making ugly vertical lines on cylinders.

I successfully made a part where the number of teeth is input and the rest is calculated and built from that number. The tooth profile is always the same. The spacing between teeth is always the same, dictated by the chain. So then the radius of the whole thing from the center is based on the number of teeth only.

The Marines were initially kept under the umbrella of the Army’s command structure, they weren’t officially separated and formed as their own division until the end of the First Tevarin War. The UPE felt that they needed a consolidated special operations force that commanded the best of both the Army and the Navy. Their focus and primary application became planetary invasion. Marine units are specialized to be weapons of warfare, nothing more. They don’t handle diplomatic escorts or pull guard duty, they dust things. When the Imperator doesn’t need them, the Marines sequester themselves to their planet-bases on Corin (Kilian system) and train for the next conflict that will require their services.

Marine-Candidates are selected from the general pool of Army and Navy recruits. The criterion for selection is unknown and inconsistent at best. Some speculate that it is intentional to cement the fact that you don’t apply to be a Marine.

I Found this dude while cleaning up the Prospector holoviewer model, and Figured I'd make a dude to stand by my models. At this small scale don't expect much detail. Feel free to scale him larger if you want to display him by himself.

remixed_from.author: pheneeny
remixed_from.title: AM8 - Metal Frame for Anet A8

title: Anet AM8 Variant
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is basically the same as the original AM8 https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2263216, except for the side extrusion.
I used 364 mm long 2040 extrusions instead of the 340 mm long. In doing so, I recovered the 24mm that I lost with the 340mm rail. Also, mi machine is not colliding any more when I pause the printer.
With this change, you continue to use the stock software. I hear so many bad stories when upgrading to Skynet that I prefered to do this.
You will find different parts that I had to make to assemble it properly.
Changes are:
364mm instead of 340mm 2040 Extrusions
Also find other items attached, which I used for this assembly.
Some parts are from Anet AM8 additions https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2283772
Fan cover is from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2051085
Front Smooth rod holders, Left supplied, make a mirror for the right side.
The front holders have a stop inside, that way only 8mm of the rod goes in. this allows you to recover 12mm at the front.
Distance from the Back of the Bottom Horizontal extrusion to the back of the vertical extrusion, will be 139mm instead of the 127mm that the original AM8 calls for. and then thats how we recover the other 12mm..
To mount the bed wire constrainer, the h-frame must be drilled and countersunk from the bottom to use flat screws to avoid collision with the screw in the back smooth rod holder.
I do really thanks Pheneeny for such a wonderful design.
I've built 3 in total so far, 2 oranges with the original design and one with my changes.
I'm in the process of making a fourth one in black and red and instead of using the stock smooth rods for the extruder carriage, I will use 2020 extrusion and if possible, I'm planning to also eliminate the vertical smooth rods and use the vertical 2040 extrusions as guides. If all goes on wheels, I should publish it within 3 weeks.

Update: There is a jig designed to set the 139mm from back of the printer to back of the vertical extrusion; is available at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2464467
Update: Added carriage wires constrainer
Update: added display adapter and bracket that avoid the screw of the tensioner to collide wit the display.

Printer:

AM8

Notes:

I like strong parts for the printer so I printed some part at 80 and some at 40% infill, all resolutions at .12, Speed: 80, Some parts have 3 walls but most parts only 2 walls. Use your own judgement on how strong you need your parts.

comments.text: Any update to this?  I'm very interested in doing likewise.  It seems like the underlying issue with most people's printers is the whole smooth rod guide approach to the linear movement.  The unsupported lead screw is also a big issue.  From what I've researched on OpenBuilds V-Slot, most of the frame components of the AM8 mod could be replaced with their V-Slot extrusions which would double up as linear bearing surfaces.  I really like their lead screw design which traps both ends of the lead screw eliminating any wobble.  I've been playing around with SketchUp trying to incorporate those components directly into the frame construction.  Just wondering if you've made any progress towards this.  Thanks.

Well, You should only add to the bottom extrusions whatever length you are adding to the heat bed size. If you add 80mm (your case), add 80mm to the extrusions.
364mm (Extrusion)-220mm (Bed)=144mm clearance,
444mm (new extrusion)-300 (new bed)= 144mm clearance

Just follow his design and use his parts, except for the front y rod holders. follow instructions about the 139mm from the back of the bottom back extrusion and the back of the vertical extrusions.
comments.author: ranita

comments.text:
Hi there,
I just ran across your design while looking for other AM8 additions and I don't really understand what this is about.
I built my AM8 using the original 340mm extrusions. Where exactly are 24mm lost? I can reach every spot on my original A8 heatbed with my 340mm extrusions. Am I missing something here?
comments.author: ranita

comments.text:
MTjoker
If you pause the printing, the bed will collide with the front extrusion.
The original anet A8 front and back acrillic plates measure 8mms thick. if you deduct a total of 16mms from the 380mms smooth rods, leaves 364mm inside clearance. When you use 340mm T-slot extrusion and add the 40 mms of the front and back extrusion, you still get 380 mms from back to front, but this time, you must deduct 40mms from the 380 mms smooth rods and you only get 340mms inside clearance, hence you must add the 24mms to the "Y" t-slot extrusions if you do not want to play with marlin or skynet.
Hope is clear enough.

description.text:
This is an ABS shrink test.

Each of the internal dimension test STLs are a 10mm tall strip with 10 holes of increasing size (1mm increase). The provided STLs go from 1 to 10mm, 11 to 20mm, 21 to 30mm, 31 to 40mm, and 41 to 50mm.

The external dimension test STL is a 10mm thick piece with dimensions from 2mm to 30mm by 2mm steps. Each step is 4mm to accommodate the width of caliper for measurement.

My conclusion from doing this is that with current slicers, the smaller than internal feature, the more shrinkage there. However, shrinkage of external features is roughly constant at an almost negligible 0.013% with my particular setup.

To negate the effects of shrinkage, the results suggest that I should scale my holes using the excel table at the CAD stage and scale my models by +0.013% at the slicing stage.

If you would like a different size or have any other questions, just let me know. If you have SolidWorks and know how to use design tables, you could generate the sizes you'd like yourself.

Printer:

Tevo Black Widow

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20

Notes:

Make sure you print both tests "laying down".

Motivation

I created this because I noticed my holes diameters would always too small, so I would have to drill them out. I looked it up and lo-and-behold, while external features shrink 0.5% to 1.0% with ABS, small hole diameters can shrink at least 8%. (Credit to Greg Williams at http://ultimaker2prints.blogspot.com/2015/02/compensating-for-abs-shrinkage.html).

To build on Greg's work, I will post graphs showing modelled dimension vs actual dimension for both internal and external dimensions (20% rectangular infill at 50mm/s with 235C nozzle, 120C heated bed in a heated chamber with MG Chemicals ABS filament). To compensate for ABS shrinkage with my particular set-up, I would need to compensate with the scalings below:

If you need help finding the appropriate scalings, just send me a message and I'll get back to you ASAP.

title: X-axis Belt Tension for STARTT (TronXY XY-100)

description.text:
This is an X-axis belt tensioner for STARTT (TronXY XY-100) printer. I used the orginal right X-axis mount file provided by iMakr and modified the file to accomodate the tensioner fork. All hardware used came with the STARTT printer.

Some of the concepts used were from "X Axis motor mount for Anet A8 or Prusa i3" posted by Randino.

See Misc. Notes for assembly details.

Printer:

STARTT

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Printed with PLA

Assembly Build Instructions

  1. After parts are printed, break the supports from the Right X-Axis.
    a. You may need to perform some secondary operations depending on how the supports break away.
  2. Make sure that all the components fit together before unassembling your printer.
  3. Once you have confirmed printed parts fit together, take the entire X-axis off from the Z-axis.
  4. Take out the screws that runs thru the idler bearing for the X-axis.
  5. Pull the OEM Right X-axis off of the two X-axis rods.
  6. Remove the coupler for the Right X-axis lead screw.
  7. Install the coupler onto the newly printed Right X-axis.
  8. Slide the nut into the newly printed Tensioner Fork.
  9. Get the X-axis belt and loop it around the idler bearing.
  10. Place the idler bearing into the Tensioner Fork with the belt looped around the bearing.
  11. Press the newly printed Right X-axis onto the X-axis rods (some force required).
  12. Install the Tensioner Fork into the Right X-axis.

(i have not completely finished installation instructions, but will complete soon)

title: EXT/USB Port Cover for Kites Game Boy Zero SAIO Kit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I could't find a suitable cover for my Game Boy Zero. Typical USB plugs either dont fit or are ugly. The standard EXT cover doesn't fit without some HAIRY work with an exacto knife. Even then you risk cracking the plastic or end up with a jagged looking cover. So I decided to remix a model that gave me the standard outer cover but modeled my own tag to press fit into the port. Mine sits snug enough to not fall or shake out but lightly enough that it can be extracted without much effort. This print is oriented such that the layers run parallel with the tab to prevent the tab from snapping off and getting stuck in the port.

The side that sits flush with the case was based on the original design by newdaynow (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1154670) and chopped off and resized to serve as a base for my USB port tab.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Prusa Mk2

100

It should fit lightly sung into the slot with just enough of a gap between the lip and the case to get a finger nail in to remove it.

title: Tak Piece Cutting Jig
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This jig is made to cut a 1" square and/or 1-1/8" round dowel with a standard miter back saw. There is an end stop for a 10mm slice (~3/8" after sanding), and a spot to place the discs to cut a flat. The end stop is intentionally short so the pieces can fall free and the stock moved up without having to put the saw down. The second holder is to support the length at a greater distance. There are screw holes for #6 or #8 drywall screws. that can be used to screw it down to a 1x2 or other support.

I have a portable work bench with clamping sections. I made the bottom plates to work with M3 bolts to clamp down on a slot of my workbench which secures it entirely satisfactorily. #6 bolts would likely work just as well. The holes may need to be expanded a bit, but should be tappable. (actually ended up tapping for 8-32)

I printed the jig and support with 3 walls and 15% infill, the clamp plates with 4 walls and 35% infill.

comments.text: This is a great idea.  I bought a piece of hexagonal brass stock, but butchered it trying to use my bandsaw.  A simple jig like this would've given much better results!

title: Main shaft seal for traxxas slash 4x4 HCG model 1

description.text:
So I design this rubber component that I call Main shaft seal for traxxas slash 4x4 HCG model 1 for the purpose of covering up the opening in the chassis where the main shaft comes out. Why because many traxxas slash 4 x 4 owners had issues in regards to the wide opening between the chassis and the main shaft. Because small rocks and debris get in there and could cause problems with the RC vehicle. As a result many owners have attempted to address this issue buy rigging up contraptions to address this issue. Since I have the means so I decided to address this issue by designing this rubber component that I called main shaft seal this component is made out of ninjaflex filament. So I had this component 3D printed out at one of my local hobby shops. So after having this 3D printed component made I tested it out on my slash 4x4 and as a result I had to make some adjustments to get everything flowing right otherwise I was successful with the installation. If you wish to download this file this component must be made of ninjaflex filament or similar filament. Also you will need Super Glue to glue it on to the chassis of the RC vehicle and the photo should give you an idea how to install it. and the photos should give you an idea how it should look after this 3D component is installed. So enjoy this upgrade.

But I must warn you be very careful with the super glue and be ready to make adjustments on the Mainshaft seal itself to make sure the drive shaft is doing his job freely as possible.

author: gonzalor

description.text: This is a 3d model of teh RX-78-2's Standard Issue Beam Rifle. Equip your scale models with this high tech weapon.

print_settings.Notes:: Requires a total of 8 M4 nylon locknuts.  Remove the stock leveling wheels, and use one of the locknuts to keep the screw in place on the hot bed (being the nut all the way to the top,. making the screw stay in place without the need to hold the top with a screwdriver).  Then replace the springs.  Insert the remaining M4 locknuts into the wheels and thread them on - wala!

description.text:
Update 9/25/17

I just added two versions that should work for the S4 and S5 as well, one 23mm in diameter, the other 35mm - please let me know!

I don't know of too many people who like to level their beds unless they have to, so why don't the leveling knobs have locknuts to help keep them from backing off as the plate bounces back and forth?

Inspired by Valstrath's "CR-10 Ultimate Leveling Knob Attachment" (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2408748), I created a wheel that does away with the OEM inserts entirely, and uses an M4 nylon lock nut - ensuring that the wheel does not move once you have adjusted it into place. Hopefully this will help tame the CR10 (or any other bed that uses M3 screws)

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

15

Notes:

Requires a total of 8 M4 nylon locknuts. Remove the stock leveling wheels, and use one of the locknuts to keep the screw in place on the hot bed (being the nut all the way to the top,. making the screw stay in place without the need to hold the top with a screwdriver). Then replace the springs. Insert the remaining M4 locknuts into the wheels and thread them on - wala!

comments.text:
CR-10s5 - The 35mm knobs work fine. To be clear, despite what you see in someone's "I made this" photo these are NOT in-addition-to the original knobs. They replace the original knobs: That's why the other guy said the bed screws were too short.
1 - Remove the 4 original knobs completely.
2 - Push the bed screws up and out.
3 - Tilt the bed off to the left (remember there are still wires connecting it)
4 - Put the 4 screws back in
5 - Put on the nylok nuts to secure the screws so they can't turn when you twist the knobs
6 - Put the bed back on the carriage including the springs. My CR10-s5 already used 4 washers each as spacers. Now that the nyloks are in place I only used one washer at the bottom of the spring. So all the spacing remains unchanged.
7 - Insert nylok into the new knobs you just printed. This is why these are locking knobs.I had to press them in with pliers.
8 - Put the new knobs on
9 - Open a fresh Mt. Dew.
comments.author: tlhIntoq

comments.text: I noticed similar problems to what others have expressed the added nylon nut creates clearance problems with a 40mm spring. My glass/faketac and bed look thicker on the CR-10S.  I was able to get the zstop to click by applying leverage to tighten all 4 corners to beyond max compression and moving the Zstop to its highest stock position. I think you would only need to remove 1mm somehow from anywhere above the black metal plate or raise your Zstop that distance. I unfortunately got a little zealous trimming my springs and need to wait for new ones before I can try any other fixes.
comments.author: grakef

comments.text: Was able to get all of them working except the corner with the heat bed brace. I changed to just a nut(non locking) which saved 1.9 mm of space. This works much better and won't move if you torque down the nut. If your worried about it backing out you could use just a very very small drop of blue thread lock. Heat bed side require me using additional leverage to get it low enough to tram the head, but I was able to get .2mm with heated bed, but it took a lot of work.
comments.author: grakef

comments.text: Why bother with putting the additional M4 lock nuts directly under the bed? Shouldn't the lock nuts within the knobs be sufficient?
comments.author: justinsane98

comments.text: If you do not put the lock nut on the bottom of the bed, you will not be able to tighten the springs with the wheel, as the screw will turn when you turn the wheel, and not tighten or loosen,  In order to access the top of the screw to hold it in place, you would need to remove the glass, which would then make it not even any more ;)

comments.text: I just tried all the lock nuts that I have and the only one that screws on to both stock printers is a 8-32 Nylon Insert Lock Nut. I haven't added any larger bolts. They are the stock bolts that go through the aluminum build plate, through stock yellow colored springs, through a black metal plate with rollers, and then the black adjustment 'nuts' that I was planning to replace with these.

print_settings.Notes:: You should only need supports for one of the parts, and you could probably use a lower resolution and still have the mechanism function just fine.
print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
The Geneva Mechanism designed by Angus from Makers Muse, I modified it to be fully 3D printable, no hardware required, although some sanding might help it run smoother.

The Geneva mechanism an elegant way to translate continuous rotation into intermittent motion. It’s classically used for movie projectors and is responsible for that iconic sound they make. It’s also used occasionally for indexable machines and CNC tool changing, and in some mechanical watches.
Wiki link: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geneva_drive
(Note: I changed the crank after test printing, so it should fit better and be easier to use)

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1 or .2

Infill:

15

Notes:

You should only need supports for one of the parts, and you could probably use a lower resolution and still have the mechanism function just fine.

description.text: Hand screw driver holders

Here is is a camera gimbal made for Sony HDR-AS15.
I am using:
  • Alexmos SimpleBGC
  • 2x Quanum 2208 Precision Brushless Gimbal Motor from HK
    • I intend to use it on a quad copter.

I have printed all the parts in ABS with 50% fill. The pitch bracket Is made of 3 parts for easier printing. (I have included a complete version as well if you prefer this). I have used acetone to glue the 3 part bracket together. Frame bracket is also glued to main holder. Screws used is M2.5 on one side and comes with the motor. On the other side of motor is M3. You need 8 screws of each dimension.
The screw that holds the camera is M3 as well and is just screwed in to the abs.

author: kmmarlow

title: Aurebesh Letters for embedding into other projects

description.text:
These are the Aurebesh letters from the font readout traced in to .stl. They are not separated into individual letters, you'll have to do that yourself, and save the original file so you can go back to it later.

NOT a finished product, this one file is made of many smaller parts to be scaled up or down to YOUR particular project. I do suggest you delete what you don't need, then separate the letters you do need, and save the original file for later uses. I have included the pic I used to trace them out as a reference to what each letter corresponds to.

I hope you can use these in your projects, please do attribute me for the letters, that woudl be nice to see ;)

author: Greg1prior

description.text:
I've been wanting to do a case modded Chumby for quite some time. I bought the Chumby One for $50 quite a long time ago from Woot and started it up once then tore it apart. It sat like that for a while, then I bought the radio off ebay. Luckily the clock opening was close to the correct size for the Chumby screen. I sat on it for a while until I got my Makerbot. The radio and clock internals are on a removable chassis held into the body by 2 screws, I decided to use this same basic idea for my Chumby mod because I didn't want to permanently modify the radio. The base plate is a piece of aluminum sheet and the various components are riveted in place. All the Chumby components are held in place with the screws that originally held them together. Problems/Future Plans:
One of the knobs from the radio wasn't reused (under the screen), this might get made into a power button.
The screen holder back plate had to be bend a bit to work. (I also didn't want to print another screen holder).
Make a back cover.
Make a cover to hide the gap around the screen.
There was no other way to attach the screen, so the holder is hot glued onto the case, but this is easily removed.
Some Chumby apps are no longer supported, a big example being Twitter.
*I broke the microphone connector and may fix it and add this back later.

• Strip down your Chumby. iFixit has a guide: http://www.ifixit.com/Teardown/chumby-one-Teardown/1614/1#.T9OvDbX4Ido (Pay special attention to removing the screen.)
  • Disassemble your radio. Be careful and just check your own radio. I own a couple and they all seem to have the same 2 screws holding in a chassis construction.
  • Cut a base plate and drill holes in the correct places to attach it to the case.
  • Print the parts and arrange them inside the case on the base plate. Mark the locations.
  • Drill the holes out for attaching the stands and rivet them in place.
  • Some components are attached with small aluminum stands. There are rather easy to make by using basic box shapes and rivets.
  • Lengthen your connector wires as necessary.
  • Attach your components to the stands.
  • Connect everything and enjoy.

description.text:
This is a Lithophane/Night Light combo that uses IKEA's LJUSTER LED night light as the back light. It is article number 402.687.56 and currently sells for $2.99 I just pried the lens off and the holder snaps on in it's place.

For the Lithophane I used http://3dp.rocks/lithophane/
My settings for the lithophane were:
Curved Outer
Max size: 80
Thickness: 3
Border: 3
Thinnest layer: .8
VectorsPP: 6
base: 0
Curve: 120
Make sure the image is set as a negative; you can check by looking at the .stl and the darker areas should be thicker. Also MAKE SURE THE ASPECT RATIO IS 3:2 There are a lot of places that go into better detail about how to get a quality lithophane.

title: Sputnik Stereo 3d Camera Protecting Shell, Case

description.text:
This is a protective case for the "Sputnik" stereo medium format camera.

Features:

  • covers sources of light-leaks around the film doors and hinges
  • snaps together, for easy removal
  • holes for d-rings on each side to allow a neck strap to be added
  • tilted hotshoe for flash
  • cable release holder

This will fit the 3rd version of this camera, which is most common. Identified by the "lomo" logo on the lens (written in russian, look it up).

It will probably fit all other versions as well, as I don't think the stampings ever changed. But I can't guarantee.

Assembly instructions

-Print all the parts in the orientation provided
-glue the top to the back
-glue the strengthing parts to either side of the front
-glue the latch strengtheners to the latch
-glue the optional hotshoe to the back, left or right side
-glue the optional cable release holder to either the left or right side of the front

For strength, I recommend printing in ABS, and using abs glue to assemble.

Note: The latch and strengthening parts MUST be printed in the opposite layer orientation to the parts that they are glued to.

I also included a stabilizer if you really want it to be stable, but after putting on the parts just in the picture it worked perfectly fine, and it's probably useless.

I recommend printing this with the belt mount that I have also made, otherwise your belt could come off easily

description.text:
A bed mount for the JG aurora A3 to make sure your belt will not come loose. Your belt will not come loose. You're literally screwing in the belt into the plate mount, with the belt track mount attached. It's tricky, but it works, as seen in the picture. I screwed the belt with the track down loosely to the belt mount, and then screwed the conjoined belt loop and belt mount to the plate mount.

I recommend printing this along with the y belt tensioner that I made as well, as that's why I made this part.

Notes:

Always use rafts as it helps with "sticky" builds. I have not tried to print it without supports. Maybe it would be ok. Print time was 46m.

Jet Engine; Geared Turbofan (GTF)

For the latest jet engine for passenger planes, the Bypass Ratio is bigger and bigger to improve the engine-performance.
In order for one of them, the Geared Turbofan (GTF) is developed. 3D model for explaining this system was designed and made imaging "PW1000 series engine.

The points of the design are;

  1. Compact "Fan Drive Gear System" which has 3 to 1 Reduction Ratio. (shown by color "RED" in photos)
  2. For the rotation of each spool, the ball bearing method and the dummy bearing method are prepared.

  3. All stator vanes are omitted this time, because of avoiding rub of vanes and blades. And each rotor except LPT is designed with support so that it can be printed as one-piece.
    The blade angle is made to agree in the spool rotational direction (View from Rear).

    • HP Spool: Clockwise
    • LP Spool: Counterclockwise
    • Fan: Clockwise
  4. In addition, some parts that printing is considered difficult without support, are prepared STL file with support. The last of two digits of the file name is identified as "ws". In order to ease understanding about the contents of each part and the assembly order, parts breakdown and list are prepared.

Download files includes;
-files: STL Files
-images: Parts Breakdown for assembly Aid
-Excel File: Parts List

Purchase Parts Information;
-Bearings (Can be used Dummy BRGs instead of the followings, See Parts List)
DDL-1370ZZ (7 x 13 x 4) 2ea - For LP-Spool
689ZZ (9 x 17 x 5) 3ea - For HP-Spool and Fan
675ZZ (5 x 8 x 2.5) 2ea - Fan Drive Gear Train

-Aluminum Tubes
See Parts List

-Screws
Micro screws M1.4x3L - Appox. 60 ea - Direct screw-in to 1 mm dia hole (No nut),
Screws M2 x 6L - 4 ea, See Parts List
Screws M3 x 8L and Washer - 1 ea, See Parts List

Assembly Points

  • Standard Skill (such as Drilling, Tapping, Filing, Tightening, Painting and Gluing etc) is needed and perseverance too.
  • For gears: Deburring (removing the sharp edges etc.) is very important for smooth rotation.
  • HPC and LPC rotor: Take care when removing the support from the blades.

Total Net Print Time: Approx. 31HR

  • (Estimated as case of PLA, 0.4mm Nozzle, 0.2mm Layer Height, 40% infill and No raft and support)
    Note: When at actual print, each parameter should be adjusted by your experience.

description.text:
Remade this as shift knob for my '05 Nissan Sentra SER Spec-V

update: cut the head off and gave it supports as well as alignment holes. Now there's a top with holes and a bottom with holes and a peg (you'll need two) to put them together. The supports are decent, mine needed a little bit of file work after removal so everything was smooth to the touch. took about 5 minutes. The alignment of the pegs/top/bottom is perfect. I'm quite happy with it. It's much easier to print and the finish quality is much higher in a vertical alignment. Oh yeah and in the two piece version I pinned his ears back because they were rubbing the palm of my hand raw. Now it is much nicer to use.

title: JG Aurora A3 x belt tensioner

description.text:
X axis belt tensioner for the JG Aurora A3. Attaches to the right side of the printer, as shown in the picture. It fits like a gem, and works just as well. It can get your x axis belt tight, probably too tight. You actually need to put the parts on a certain way, with the thicker side to the right when mounting it, otherwise you should notice it doesn't fit quite right.

You need your own screws and nuts for this, but it should be good with 2*20mm M3 screws. The worst part about this if you're using a JG aurora A3 is that if you want to use the parts that are already included with the printer, such as the bearings, you have to literally take off the entire x-axis just to take out a single screw, and then put it back on, just because of a few millimeters.

description.text: Remixed from another design. Made the plug solid and slightly enlarged the threads 3 percent for a better fit. Head was shortened and made to fit a 7/8" (22mm) wrench. Use teflon tape around threads to ensure a water tight fit. I made this after the hollow plastic one on my motorhome broke.
