title: Felix 3D Printer Filament Spool Holder and Guide

description.text: (Updated Feb. 10,'14) A thingy-in-progress! I was looking for a solution for spool placement on my DIY Felix 2.0 and realized I had enough hardware left over to make a simple post-mounted spool holder myself. It fits the standard 1kg filament spool with a 50mm diameter center hole and 75mm width just fine with slight side-to-side play to reduce friction. My first file had a flaw where the extruder would hit the holder when in the x-axis home position. This spool holder's new position has been tested with an entire 1kg spool of filament with no snags or interruptions at all. Simple and functional. If you LIKE this, click on the HEART! :)

Requires only a single M4X40 (4mmX40mm) bolt and shiny metal t-slot brace that should be extra pieces in your DIY kit. Mount it at the absolute top on the outside of the wide vertical bracket as you see in the photo. The guide must be vertical. Slide the spool onto the post then simply feed it around the guide. You may have to drill the hole slightly, but my bolt threaded in fine. You may also tap the vertical post if a t-slot brace is not available.

remixed_from.author: GregoryHolloway
remixed_from.title: Original Prusa i3 MK2 E3D Titan Aero Upgrade

title: Anet A8 Titan Aero X Carriage

description.text:
This is a remix of Original Prusa i3 MK2 E3D Titan Aero Upgrade for the Anet A8. You'll need an appropriately sized fan duct from the original too. For the default Anet motors this is the 39mm duct.

I've mostly just amended the belt holder and channel to align with the 16 tooth gears as supplied with the A8. You'll probably need to use glass fibre reinforced belts (which I'd recommend using anyhow) as the supplied ones may be too thick to fit. I also recommend using it with Leo_N's Anet A8 X-Idler Mounts as the Anet A8's X rods are spaced slightly further apart. Using the Anet supplied X carriage will cause some binding of the linear bearings; it still works, but may reduce print quality and increase wear on the motors.

The Anet board seems incapable of supplying the correct current to anything other than the supplied motors. If you have the older version of the Anet board you may be to use the smaller motor as available for the Aero. There are no adjustable trimpots on my board, and I couldn't get the E3D pancake motor nor a clone to work. So as much as I didn't want to, I had to use the supplied Anet motor with the 39mm duct.

Firmware settings provided are predicated on the use of SkyNet3D/Marlin.

configuration.h settings:
#define DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT {100, 100, 400, 496}
#define DEFAULT_MAX_FEEDRATE {400, 400, 8, 1.5}
#define DEFAULT_MAX_ACCELERATION { 1000, 1000, 100, 1000 }
#define INVERT_X_DIR true
#define INVERT_E0_DIR true

Once you've done this, recompile and flash the printer with the new firmware.

For DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT the last value is the Extruder Stepper, in my case 496. Your value may well be different so use a guide to help you work it out. If you use M92 Exxx to set the value you may need to use the Load Settings option on the LCD to get the changes to apply.

The maximum feed rate is ~1/25th of the original, which seems very low, but this hasn't caused me any issues printing at 40mm/s with 0.32mm layer height. Any higher that this and my rigid.ink (referral link) PLA at 180C wasn't feeding accurately as the gear was grinding through the filament.

N.B.: M8 proximity probes don't provide enough detection range to pick up the Aluminium heat bed. And nothing bigger fits in the mount. When I get a moment I'll see about sorting an attachment for M12 or larger probes.

Edit 2017/09/011: First sensor mount is up. It fits the Tronxy XY-08N and similar. It's also adjustable enough to allow the use of an E3D Volcano hot end. Cylindrical mounts should follow pretty quickly, along with firmware offsets.

As an aside, I've switched to using Simplify3D v4 and I have to say I'm very impressed. Out of the box it prints faster (well over half an hour quicker for this model at 0.24mm and 40mm/s) with better quality than Cura 2.6.2 that I've spent weeks tweaking. I miss the ability to print directly to OctoPrint. And damn it's expensive, only about 5 quid less than I paid for the A8. But I'm sorely tempted to keep it.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.28

Infill:

16%

Notes:

These are just the settings I used, the actual resolution shouldn't matter. Just don't use more than "touching base-plate" supports otherwise you'll fill in the holes for the cable ties.

description.text:
You can see this being printed here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=31PjbtQGmJ4
Please, remember to subscribe and share the video :) (measle 6 subscribers...) I'm a big fan of Bungie games (Halo series!) and i'm loving this upcoming game Destiny already, it looks neat and well groomed. So as a tribute, i have created pendant from their symbol. I'm not sure how 2D to 3D translation process went... i did this from their 2D flat image and i'm just betting that 3D object would have filleted sides. So if your waiting for this game, print this and hang it on your neck! These were printed on 0.1 layer height and infill 100%.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

no

Notes:

Print with no infill, no bottom layer and no top layer so its hollow and the hole for the camera lens is there.
You have to trim a few strings out of the lens hole.
If that does not work, try 1 top layer and trim the camera lens hole after.
One perimeter makes it light, 2 makes it strong.
No cooling until you get to the last 10 layers, this makes it stronger, especially if your printing one perimeter.

author: Diymik

description.text: This is a box that can sit on a normal DIN rail. The Raspberry PI will be placed on it's long side standing. Then you can add whatever "extensions" you need. :) I'm using this in our Greenhouse. It's equipped with an Automation Hat and a Adafruit 16-Channel PWM / Servo HAT for the Raspberry PI 3. I'm also using two power step down modules. One for converting to 5v (for the PI, SPI, DHT and other low volt stuff) and one for converting to 12v (going though the relays). These are powered with an old Lenovo laptop adapter via the round power plug. Then I'm using the PiCam-Extension Base for this Pi Camera HDMI Cable Extension to be able to use a 5 meter HDMI cable fot the PI-Camera (so, yes the HDMI-port you see on the pictures are NOT for the screen). You will have to get a bit creative with "raisers" and spacers to get the HAT's to sit at different heights. I have included some M3 spacers and a M3 adapter that you can use to "prolong" M3 screws. Also the SketchUp files is now included. :)

title: Sail Curtain for my Boat Speedy 540

description.text:
In order to build this object you need to print:

2 Keel Hook
8 Hook Lock
4 Rotary Hook
6 Rotary Hook for curtain pipes

Please, print those objects using Pet-G. It is elastic so it "should" resist more than an object printed using ABS Do not use PLA because hot temperature will damage the printed objects.
The structure is composed by different 20mm alluminium pipes. The dimension depends on the boat dimension so it must be evaluated during the setup.
The rotary hooks are built for a 22mm keel pipes so, if your pipes are different you will need to adapt the pipe Screws and bolts are well dimensioned and should be of the required measure.
At the top of the structure pipes should be connected with curve objects not included in this draw. This because you can easelly (and it is cheaper than printing the object on your own) find those objects in any forinuture shop. I used the curve connectors used for the plastic pipes needed as protection for electric cable.
Please note that this draw is only for the structure. The cloth, curtain connections are not part of the draw and should be adapted to your needs and to your dimensions

For more others ideas and objects, please visit: http://www.buonevacanze.org/

author: Vincentpartman

title: Improved Tiny Whoop / Inductrix / E010 FPV frame 3 grams.

description.text:
Hi, everybody!

After long loooong nights searching the internet for the best available TW/E010/Micro FPV quad frame I ended up looking at very expensive but still breakable CF/Alu frames that weigh around 6 to 8 grams. Other frames where 3D printed but in such a way that they mimic the original TW or E010 frames, this means they are still breakable and heavier than necessary.

I finally decided to give it a go and started to design my own frame, I already had a set of minimum requirements based on previous experiences with small FPV quads.
I tried to achieve the following requirements in the design of this frame:

  • Light @ only 3 grams,
    Simply everybody with Tiny Whoop experience knows why this is so important!

  • Durable,
    Since you don`t want to have to rebuild the quad after every crash.

  • PropGuards,
    Continue flying after you hit the wall, chair, table, etc and minimize the impact on the electronics.

  • Cheap,
    3D print it yourself or ask a friend.. almost everybody has a printer near him these days..
    Let's do the math: a 1000grams roll of PLA costs approximately 20Euro`s.
    1000/3 grams means 333 frames per roll! that's 0,06Euro per frame.

  • Easy to build and reproduce,
    Building this frame will take you only 15- 20minutes after printing of course.

The latest version is V1.2, this version has the H-shaped section in the middle to hold the battery. A small rubber band is used to hold the battery and is attached to the outer flight controller mounting screws then runs along the bottom of the frame over the H section. Total weight excluding battery will be approximately 21Grams.
my setup: 6mm coreless motors 59000rpm, bee-core, 1s 200~300mAh battery.

For flight computers, I fitted the Beecore_F3 but I am pretty sure the Inductrix and bee brain FC will fit without any problems.

Give it a try and please share your builds and experiences!

Checkout the RCGroups thread as well: https://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showthread.php?2933423-Another-Inductrix-TW-E010-(FPV)-3D-printed-frame-design!

EDITS:
14-08-2017 > Added a 7mm motor version of the frame.
2-10-2017 > Added a new 7mm version, the frame is slightly bigger which makes it easier
to fit the props, motor mount dimension are changed as well so they fit if
printed at 100% This 7mm version really is a blast to fly compared to 6mm!
2-10-2017> Another update today, I have added bigger frame for 7mm motors that can fit
46mm props.

Printer:

ANET A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20

Infill:

25%

Notes:

-------- Picture of my print settings added to the photos list --------
230 degrees is set for PET-G

I printed these frames in PLA and PET-G, will try semi flex materials later as well and post my experience with them.
Make sure to let the bed cool down before you remove the part!!!
There is a possibility it will bend if your bed is at 50 Degrees like mine is when printing PLA.

Motor fitting after printing

Depending on the settings of your printer you may experience difficulties fitting the 6mm coreless motors. I used a soldering Iron to remove any edges or chips on the inside of the motor mounts, make sure to do this outdoors and off-course don`t inhale any fumes!
Make sure to only remove the chips or edges on the bottom of the mounts, don't widen the motor-mounts to much and don't remove the edges on the top of the motor mounts. These are specifically designed to keep the motors from sliding upwards.
